title: The Value I've Found in Writing Openly and Honestly About Major Depressive Disorder

content: Trust me: I can already hear those of a certain generation or gender suck their teeth after reading the title of my blog and label me dramatic or attention seeking. As if I've ever wanted anything close to pity or sympathy from such folks. As if I’ve ever asked them for anything in my entire life, when in reality many of them I’ve likely never met.

But that doesn't stop them from presuming it's safe to judge me for openly discussing my experience with depression in some of the most belittling ways possible. This has little to no effect on my life, as I was taught by someone far wiser than me what a waste of time worrying what others think about you truly is.
It would be better if you quietly asked yourself what, exactly, you're so mad about and actually let what comes to mind out. Even if it's just for you to ponder rather than for public consumption.

content: However, I must say: The thought that something I write has the potential to help someone going through the exact same thing feel even slightly better leaves me feeling just a little better off than I did before I sat down to write.

Because no matter how down we may feel, once you find a cause or purpose you believe in, or a calling you feel was custom made just for you, it's far more difficult to walk through the world as a cynical and pessimistic misanthrope who takes pride in their ill-conceived observations or miscalculated perceptions of the world and the people who inhabit it. People just like them that they're connected to in ways beyond comprehension whether they like it or not. Humans have always seemed to be better at finding what makes us different than what makes us similar, which only causes division where there could and should be cooperation and cohesion.

I write for me as much as I write with the hopes and intentions of helping another who may be struggling in the same ways I am or have. Some days it's more for my own emotional well-being and on others, it's my way of letting anyone reading know that they are far from alone and have nothing to be ashamed of.
